content.question: For a certain population of men, 8 percent carry a certain genetic trait. For a certain population of women, 0.5 percent carry the same genetic trait. Let <math alttext="P hat sub 1" overflow="scroll"> <mrow> <msub> <mrow> <mover> <mrow> <mi>p</mi> </mrow> <mrow> <mo>^</mo> </mrow> </mover> </mrow> <mrow> <mn>1</mn> </mrow> </msub> </mrow> </math> represent the sample proportion of randomly selected men from the population who carry the trait, and let <math overflow="scroll"> <mrow> <msub> <mrow> <mover> <mrow> <mstyle> <mrow> <mi>p</mi> </mrow> </mstyle> </mrow> <mrow> <mo>^</mo> </mrow> </mover> </mrow> <mrow> <mn>2</mn> </mrow> </msub> </mrow> </math> represent the sample proportion of women from the population who carry the trait. For which of the following sample sizes will the sampling distribution of <math alttext="P hat sub 1 minus P hat sub 2" overflow="scroll"> <mstyle> <mrow> <msub> <mrow> <mover> <mrow> <mi>p</mi> </mrow> <mrow> <mo>^</mo> </mrow> </mover> </mrow> <mrow> <mn>1</mn> </mrow> </msub> <mo>âˆ’</mo> <msub> <mrow> <mover> <mrow> <mi>p</mi> </mrow> <mrow> <mo>^</mo> </mrow> </mover> </mrow> <mrow> <mn>2</mn> </mrow> </msub> </mrow> </mstyle> </math> be approximately normal?

topic.text: 5.6: Sampling Distributions for Differences in Sample Proportions
